questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of bilateral blurry vision and difficulty driving at night that has been worsening progressively over the past 5 months. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. His hemoglobin A1c concentration is 8.9%. A slit-lamp shows cloudy opacities of the lenses bilaterally. The patient's eye condition is most likely due to increased activity of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Galactokinase catalyzes the conversion of galactose to galactose-1-phosphate. Deficiency of this enzyme, not overactivation, causes mild galactosemia (galactokinase deficiency), resulting in cataract formation due to accumulation of galactitol in the lens of the eye.

B) INCORRECT:

Aldolase B is predominantly expressed in the liver and converts fructose-1-phosphate to dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP) and glyceraldehyde. No specific pathologic condition has been associated with overactivity of this enzyme. Its deficiency does however result in hereditary fructose intolerance, which typically presents with hypoglycemia (due to inhibition of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis) and vomiting following consumption of fructose-containing food.
Image Description:

(1) Essential fructosuria is an inherited benign metabolic disorder that is due to a deficiency of the fructokinase enzyme within the liver.

(2) Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive defect in the fructose metabolism pathway due to an aldolase B enzyme deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucokinase is a hexokinase isoenzyme exclusively present in the liver and beta cells of the pancreas, promoting glucose storage and insulin secretion, respectively. Unlike hexokinase, it has low affinity and high capacity for glucose and is inducible by insulin. It has no role in cataract formation.

D) CORRECT:

Aldose reductase catalyzes the reduction of glucose to sorbitol, which is subsequently oxidized to fructose by sorbitol dehydrogenase enzyme. At normal blood glucose levels, only a small part of glucose is metabolized via this polyol pathway. However, in chronic hyperglycemia due to poorly controlled diabetes, sorbitol formation increases significantly, causing osmotic damage in tissues with low sorbitol dehydrogenase activity (e.g., lens, retina, kidney, and myelin sheath). Consequently, patients present with retinopathy, nephropathy, peripheral neuropathy, and bilateral cataracts as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

During hyperglycemic states, excess glucose is shunted from the hexokinase/glycolysis pathway into various other metabolic pathways. Cells containing aldose reductase convert glucose to sorbitol, which is then converted into fructose. Organs lacking sorbitol dehydrogenase (red) accumulate sorbitol, resulting in osmotic damage.

E) INCORRECT:

Sorbitol dehydrogenase converts sorbitol into fructose, which can be used as energy substrate in the liver and seminal vesicles. The activity of this enzyme is low in the retina and lens. Hence, during chronic hyperglycemia, sorbitol can accumulate in these tissues, causing bilateral cataracts as seen in this patient. However, increased activity of this enzyme is not associated with any specific pathologic conditions.
questions.hint: This patient's physical examination shows bilateral cataracts, most likely due to his poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive worsening of vision in both eyes over the past 6 months. The patient reports that during this period he has had blurry vision and a glare in the evenings. He works as a tower crane operator and spends most of his day outdoors. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/100 in both eyes. A photograph of the left eye is shown. Damage to which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Opacification of the aqueous humor typically occurs in acute uveitis, a condition in which pus accumulates in the anterior chamber (hypopyon). However, opacification would not be restricted to the pupillary area, as seen here. Instead, it would be present in the inferior region of the anterior chamber and obscure the underlying iris. Moreover, the chronic nature of the patient's symptoms and the absence of pain and conjunctival injection make a different kind of ocular damage more likely.
Image Description:

Left eye

Massive mixed injections are present. Iris details appear blurred, which may result from corneal edema or inflammatory infiltration of the anterior chamber. The pupil (green overlay) is not completely round, which may be due to posterior synechiae. White material can be seen in the inferior region of the anterior chamber (hypopyon, blue overlay).

The massive inflammatory process seen here could be due to, e.g., postoperative endophthalmitis or very severe uveitis.

Dashed line: surrounds cornea

B) INCORRECT:

Corneal edema, which can be caused by keratitis, anterior uveitis, acute closed-angle glaucoma, and certain metabolic disorders (e.g., mucopolysaccharidoses), would appear as opacifications on slit-lamp examination and cause impaired visual acuity. However, such opacifications would not be restricted to the pupillary area, as is the case here. Instead, opacification would be present throughout the cornea and obscure the underlying iris.
Image Description:

There is white-gray clouding of the cornea, making details of the iris appear blurred.

Corneal clouding is seen in a variety of diseases (here: mucopolysaccharidosis VI).

C) INCORRECT:

Vitreous body pathologies, such as persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) and chronic ocular toxocariasis, can result in impaired visual acuity and leukocoria. However, PHPV typically occurs during childhood, and toxocariasis is accompanied by ocular pain. Moreover, both conditions are typically unilateral, whereas both eyes are affected in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Gradual, painless loss of vision, glare, and leukocoria in an adult is consistent with cataract. Symptoms develop secondary to clouding of the lens. Cataracts often occur bilaterally and are the most common cause of impaired vision in individuals over 40 years of age. Besides chronic UV exposure, other risk factors for cataracts include advanced age, diabetes mellitus, smoking, heavy alcohol consumption, chronic corticosteroid therapy, and ocular trauma.

Conditions associated with congenital and juvenile cataracts include galactosemia, chromosomal trisomies, certain TORCH infections (e.g., rubella, toxoplasmosis), Marfan syndrome, Alport syndrome, myotonic dystrophy, and neurofibromatosis type II.

E) INCORRECT:

Retinal pathologies such as retinoblastoma, retrolental fibroplasia, and Coats disease can cause leukocoria with impaired visual acuity. However, these conditions typically occur in children.
Image Description:

Leukocoria, i.e., a white pupillary reflex, is present in the left eye. The right eye shows normal retinal reflection.

Leukocoria can have various causes, including as cataracts, Coats disease, and, as in this case, retinoblastoma.
questions.hint: The photograph shows leukocoria (white pupillary reflex). Chronic UV exposure (e.g., from working outdoors) is a risk factor for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively blurry vision. About 3 years ago, she stopped using her reading glasses for several months because her eyesight improved temporarily. She is a landscape painter. For the past year, she has mostly been working inside her studio instead of outside her house. She comments that “the bright sunlight makes me see halos around lights and then I cannot distinguish between the nuances of colors anymore.” The patient recently stopped driving at night because she no longer trusts her eyes. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, asthma, and atrial fibrillation. She has smoked 1.5 packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years and occasionally drinks 1–2 glasses of wine. Her medications include metformin, albuterol, budesonide-formoterol, digoxin, and rivaroxaban. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min and irregular, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/80 in both eyes. On fundoscopic examination, the retina is hard to visualize and the red reflex appears darkened. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administration of topical pilocarpine and timolol

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravitreous injection of bevacizumab is the first-line treatment for patients with exudative age-related macular degeneration (wet AMD), which can cause progressive and painless loss of vision. However, wet AMD affects one eye first rather than both eyes, and progresses over weeks to months rather than years. Additionally, this condition does not cause a temporary improvement in near vision, darkening of the red reflex, and obscuration of the ocular fundus. Finally, the visual impairment is usually central or pericentral and patients generally present with metamorphopsia and scotomas, none of which are seen here.

B) CORRECT:

Surgical replacement of the lens is the treatment of choice for patients with cataracts with significant cataract-related visual impairment, as seen in this patient. The standard surgical technique is extracapsular cataract extraction. There is no pharmacological therapy available except in galactosemia, in which the cataract is reversible when following a galactose-free diet. Untreated cataracts eventually lead to complete blindness.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp examination of the left eye

There is cloudy white opacification of the entire lens (green overlay). As a result, the red reflex is absent.

An additional finding is a posterior synechia (arrow), as the superior part of the pupil is not completely round.

C) INCORRECT:

Laser photocoagulation of the retina is used in the treatment of both proliferative (PDR) and nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR). Diabetic retinopathy is the most common cause of visual impairment in patients aged 25–74 years in the US and can also cause bilateral, progressive, painless vision loss. However, diabetic retinopathy is not associated with the visualization of halos around lights, a temporary improvement in near vision, or the darkening of the red reflex. Characteristic fundoscopic findings of PDR include preretinal neovascularization, vitreous hemorrhage, retinal detachment, and fibrovascular proliferation, while characteristic fundoscopic findings of NPDR include hard exudates and macular ischemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical latanoprost is the preferred first-line treatment for patients with open-angle glaucoma, which also causes bilateral, progressive vision loss that can be associated with halos around lights. Advanced age, diabetes mellitus, and steroid use, all of which are seen in this patient, are known risk factors for open-angle glaucoma. However, a temporary improvement in near vision and a fundoscopy showing darkening of the red reflex and obscuration of ocular fundus are not expected. Additionally, in patients with open-angle glaucoma, the visual field loss progresses from peripheral to central over time, which is not seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical pilocarpine and timolol are the first-line treatment for acute angle-closure glaucoma, which can cause blurred vision associated with halos around lights and manifest with a hard to visualize retina (due to corneal opacification). However, acute angle-closure glaucoma is usually unilateral rather than bilateral, and patients typically present with a red, painful eye with a fixed pupil, which is not seen here. Additionally, the visual impairment has a sudden onset rather than a progressive course. Furthermore, beta blockers should be avoided in this patient with asthma because of the risk of bronchoconstriction.

F) INCORRECT:

Blurred vision is a common side effect of digoxin therapy, affecting 1–10% of patients taking this cardiac glycoside. However, digoxin therapy is not associated with halos around lights, temporary improvement in near vision, darkening of the red reflex, or obscuration of the ocular fundus. Other visual side effects of digoxin therapy include central scotomas, photopsia, diplopia, and dyschromatopsia. Finally, further side effects (gastrointestinal, neurological) would be expected in the case of digoxin toxicity.
questions.hint: This patient's bilateral progressive, painless loss of vision, halos around lights, reduced night vision, and temporary near vision improvement, along with darkening of the red reflex and obscuration of the ocular fundus indicate bilateral cataracts. Risk factors for cataract formation include advanced age, diabetes mellitus, and smoking, all of which are seen here.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man reports a gradual decline in the quality of his vision. He is especially bothered by glare from oncoming headlights when he is driving.
On examination, his best-corrected visual acuity is 20/60 in each eye. His eyes are not injected, and he reports no eye pain. His optic nerves and retinas, as viewed through a direct ophthalmoscope, appear normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cataracts occur as the natural lens of the eye becomes denser and slightly discolored with age. They typically begin to develop around age 50 but usually do not become visually significant until age 60 to 70. Patients describe a haze or overall lack of clarity to their vision, and glare becomes more problematic; complaints about night driving are very common. Cataracts often cause a myopic shift in a patient’s eyeglass prescription.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an older patient who reports problems with glare and decreasing visual acuity is cataracts.

B) INCORRECT:

Uveitis is associated with a red, painful eye and photophobia; and older age is not a risk factor.

C) INCORRECT:

Macular degeneration is associated with a loss of visual acuity, and images can appear distorted, but this condition does not generally cause problems with glare. Drusen (localized deposits of extracellular material that appear as small, yellow areas on funduscopic examination) are characteristic findings of age-related macular degeneration.

D) INCORRECT:

Giant-cell arteritis causes a sudden, profound vision loss that is initially unilateral but can become bilateral if not treated immediately. This condition is typically associated with headache, jaw claudication, and weight loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary open-angle glaucoma is associated with increasing age and may cause a gradual, painless vision loss that can be bilateral; however, vision loss typically starts peripherally, with central vision being spared until advanced stages. Glare is not a common complaint in patients with glaucoma.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old boy is brought into the office by his foster mother to establish care. His birth mother (a cousin of the foster mother) was recently incarcerated, and his father is not involved. The patient has not had any previous well-child examinations, according to the foster mother.
His height, weight, and head circumference are all at the 50th percentile for his age. His physical examination is unremarkable except for nystagmus and the eye findings shown below (figure).
Which one of the following aspects of this patient’s history would be most useful to obtain from the biological mother?

choices.text: Whether the infant was large for gestational age at birth
Whether the infant has a family history of infantile glaucoma
Whether the mother had any febrile rash illnesses during pregnancy
Whether the infant has a history of group B streptococcal infection
Whether the pregnancy was complicated by chorioamnionitis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bilateral congenital cataracts have been associated with low birth weight (<2000 grams), not with being large for gestational age.

B) INCORRECT:

Infantile glaucoma is usually sporadic but can also have a genetic component; it is associated with optic disk cupping, enlarged corneas, and/or orbital enlargement. It is not associated with leukocoria.

C) CORRECT:

Leukocoria (a white pupillary reflex) in both eyes suggests bilateral congenital cataracts. Cataracts in the anterior cortex are often visible to the examiner’s unaided eye but were probably missed in this patient because of his lack of previous medical evaluations.

In infants with uncorrected congenital cataracts, nystagmus develops at 2 to 3 months of age, usually related to visual deprivation; the presence of nystagmus is associated with a poor visual prognosis. Strabismus may also be present. Children with uncorrected cataracts may have delays in developmental milestones (e.g., lack of reaching for objects and tracking items with the eyes) because of poor vision.

Most unilateral congenital cataracts are developmental anomalies with no identifiable cause. In contrast, bilateral congenital cataracts are more likely to be inherited or related to a systemic cause. Up to one-third of bilateral childhood cataracts are inherited, most in an autosomal dominant fashion, although autosomal recessive and X-linked forms also exist.

Systemic causes of bilateral congenital cataracts include most of the classic TORCH intrauterine infections: toxoplasmosis, syphilis, rubella, cytomegalovirus, and herpes simplex virus. Congenital rubella syndrome is the TORCH infection most associated with congenital cataracts. Other clinical findings consistent with this syndrome include congenital heart disease (pulmonary artery stenosis and patent ductus arteriosus) and sensorineural hearing loss. Almost all cases of congenital rubella syndrome diagnosed in the United States are in infants born to women who acquired the infection in countries where rubella elimination programs are behind that of the United States.

Congenital Zika virus infection is another consideration in the workup of an infant with newly diagnosed cataracts, but it is less of a concern in this case given the absence of epidemiologic links.

Craniofacial syndromes, skeletal disorders, dermatologic disorders, metabolic disorders, ocular diseases (such as retinopathy of prematurity), and chromosomal syndromes (such as trisomies 13, 18, and 21) are also associated with congenital cataracts. Most inherited or developmental cataracts are isolated abnormalities, although referral for genetic testing may be initiated.

Key learning point: A white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) in both eyes suggests bilateral congenital cataracts.

D) INCORRECT:

Group B streptococcal infections are not risk factors for congenital cataracts.

E) INCORRECT:

Maternal chorioamnionitis is a risk factor for neonatal sepsis, but not congenital cataracts.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the office because of progressive worsening of vision in both eyes over the past 6 months. The patient reports that during this period he has had blurry vision and a glare in the evenings. He works as a tower crane operator and spends most of his day outdoors. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/100 in both eyes. A photograph of the left eye is shown. Damage to which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Opacification of the aqueous humor typically occurs in acute uveitis, a condition in which pus accumulates in the anterior chamber (hypopyon). However, opacification would not be restricted to the pupillary area, as seen here. Instead, it would be present in the inferior region of the anterior chamber and obscure the underlying iris. Moreover, the chronic nature of the patient's symptoms and the absence of pain and conjunctival injection make a different kind of ocular damage more likely.
Image Description:

Left eye

Massive mixed injections are present. Iris details appear blurred, which may result from corneal edema or inflammatory infiltration of the anterior chamber. The pupil (green overlay) is not completely round, which may be due to posterior synechiae. White material can be seen in the inferior region of the anterior chamber (hypopyon, blue overlay).

The massive inflammatory process seen here could be due to, e.g., postoperative endophthalmitis or very severe uveitis.

Dashed line: surrounds cornea

B) INCORRECT:

Corneal edema, which can be caused by keratitis, anterior uveitis, acute closed-angle glaucoma, and certain metabolic disorders (e.g., mucopolysaccharidoses), would appear as opacifications on slit-lamp examination and cause impaired visual acuity. However, such opacifications would not be restricted to the pupillary area, as is the case here. Instead, opacification would be present throughout the cornea and obscure the underlying iris.
Image Description:

There is white-gray clouding of the cornea, making details of the iris appear blurred.

Corneal clouding is seen in a variety of diseases (here: mucopolysaccharidosis VI).

C) INCORRECT:

Vitreous body pathologies, such as persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) and chronic ocular toxocariasis, can result in impaired visual acuity and leukocoria. However, PHPV typically occurs during childhood, and toxocariasis is accompanied by ocular pain. Moreover, both conditions are typically unilateral, whereas both eyes are affected in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Gradual, painless loss of vision, glare, and leukocoria in an adult is consistent with cataract. Symptoms develop secondary to clouding of the lens. Cataracts often occur bilaterally and are the most common cause of impaired vision in individuals over 40 years of age. Besides chronic UV exposure, other risk factors for cataracts include advanced age, diabetes mellitus, smoking, heavy alcohol consumption, chronic corticosteroid therapy, and ocular trauma.

Conditions associated with congenital and juvenile cataracts include galactosemia, chromosomal trisomies, certain TORCH infections (e.g., rubella, toxoplasmosis), Marfan syndrome, Alport syndrome, myotonic dystrophy, and neurofibromatosis type II.

E) INCORRECT:

Retinal pathologies such as retinoblastoma, retrolental fibroplasia, and Coats disease can cause leukocoria with impaired visual acuity. However, these conditions typically occur in children.
Image Description:

Leukocoria, i.e., a white pupillary reflex, is present in the left eye. The right eye shows normal retinal reflection.

Leukocoria can have various causes, including as cataracts, Coats disease, and, as in this case, retinoblastoma.
questions.hint: The photograph shows leukocoria (white pupillary reflex). Chronic UV exposure (e.g., from working outdoors) is a risk factor for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office because of gradual decline in the quality of his vision. He is bothered by glare from oncoming headlights when he is driving. His eyes are not injected, and he reports no eye pain. On examination, his best-corrected visual acuity is 20/60 in each eye. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cataracts occur as the natural lens of the eye becomes denser and slightly discolored with age. They typically begin to develop around age 50 but usually do not become visually significant until age 60 to 70. Patients describe a haze or overall lack of clarity to their vision, and glare becomes more problematic; complaints about night driving are very common. Cataracts often cause a myopic shift in a patient’s eyeglass prescription.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an older patient who reports problems with glare and decreasing visual acuity is cataracts.

B) INCORRECT:

Uveitis is associated with a red, painful eye and photophobia; and older age is not a risk factor.

C) INCORRECT:

Macular degeneration is associated with a loss of visual acuity, and images can appear distorted, but this condition does not generally cause problems with glare. Drusen (localized deposits of extracellular material that appear as small, yellow areas on funduscopic examination) are characteristic findings of age-related macular degeneration.

D) INCORRECT:

Giant-cell arteritis causes a sudden, profound vision loss that is initially unilateral but can become bilateral if not treated immediately. This condition is typically associated with headache, jaw claudication, and weight loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary open-angle glaucoma is associated with increasing age and may cause a gradual, painless vision loss that can be bilateral; however, vision loss typically starts peripherally, with central vision being spared until advanced stages. Glare is not a common complaint in patients with glaucoma.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to your clinic with progressive worsening of vision in both eyes over the past 6 months. He reports experiencing blurry vision and glare in the evenings during this period. He works as a tower crane operator and spends most of his day outdoors. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/100 in both eyes. A photograph of the left eye is provided. Damage to which one of the following structures is most likely responsible for his current symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Corneal edema, which can be caused by keratitis, anterior uveitis, acute closed-angle glaucoma, and certain metabolic disorders (e.g., mucopolysaccharidoses), would appear as opacifications on slit-lamp examination and cause impaired visual acuity. However, such opacifications would not be restricted to the pupillary area, as is the case here. Instead, opacification would be present throughout the cornea and obscure the underlying iris.

B) INCORRECT:

Opacification of the aqueous humor typically occurs in acute uveitis, a condition in which pus accumulates in the anterior chamber (hypopyon). However, opacification would not be restricted to the pupillary area, as seen here. Instead, it would be present in the inferior region of the anterior chamber and obscure the underlying iris. Moreover, the chronic nature of the patient's symptoms and the absence of pain and conjunctival injection make a different kind of ocular damage more likely.

C) CORRECT:

Gradual, painless loss of vision, glare, and leukocoria in an adult is consistent with cataract. Symptoms develop secondary to clouding of the lens. Cataracts often occur bilaterally and are the most common cause of impaired vision in individuals over 40 years of age. Besides chronic UV exposure, other risk factors for cataracts include advanced age, diabetes mellitus, smoking, heavy alcohol consumption, chronic corticosteroid therapy, and ocular trauma.

Conditions associated with congenital and juvenile cataracts include galactosemia, chromosomal trisomies, certain TORCH infections (e.g., rubella, toxoplasmosis), Marfan syndrome, Alport syndrome, myotonic dystrophy, and neurofibromatosis type II.

Key learning point: Cataracts cause gradual, painless vision loss and glare due to clouding of the lens, most commonly affecting adults over age 40.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitreous body pathologies, such as persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) and chronic ocular toxocariasis, can result in impaired visual acuity and leukocoria. However, PHPV typically occurs during childhood, and toxocariasis is accompanied by ocular pain. Moreover, both conditions are typically unilateral, whereas both eyes are affected in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Retinal pathologies such as retinoblastoma, retrolental fibroplasia, and Coats disease can cause leukocoria with impaired visual acuity. However, these conditions typically occur in children.
questions.hint: The photograph shows leukocoria (white pupillary reflex). Chronic UV exposure (e.g., from working outdoors) is a risk factor for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to your clinic because of a gradual decline in his vision. He reports being bothered by glare from oncoming headlights while driving. He has no eye pain and his eyes are not injected. On examination, his best-corrected visual acuity is 20/60 in each eye. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uveitis is associated with a red, painful eye and photophobia; and older age is not a risk factor.

B) CORRECT:

Cataracts occur as the natural lens of the eye becomes denser and slightly discolored with age. They typically begin to develop around age 50 but usually do not become visually significant until age 60 to 70. Patients describe a haze or overall lack of clarity to their vision, and glare becomes more problematic; complaints about night driving are very common. Cataracts often cause a myopic shift in a patient’s eyeglass prescription.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an older patient who reports problems with glare and decreasing visual acuity is cataracts.

C) INCORRECT:

Giant-cell arteritis causes a sudden, profound vision loss that is initially unilateral but can become bilateral if not treated immediately. This condition is typically associated with headache, jaw claudication, and weight loss.

D) INCORRECT:

Macular degeneration is associated with a loss of visual acuity, and images can appear distorted, but this condition does not generally cause problems with glare. Drusen (localized deposits of extracellular material that appear as small, yellow areas on funduscopic examination) are characteristic findings of age-related macular degeneration.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary open-angle glaucoma is associated with increasing age and may cause a gradual, painless vision loss that can be bilateral; however, vision loss typically starts peripherally, with central vision being spared until advanced stages. Glare is not a common complaint in patients with glaucoma.
